title: Valerie Harper, TV's Rhoda, Dies at 80
summary: Actress won three consecutive Emmys playing wise-cracking best friend on 'The Mary Tyler Moore Show'. LOS ANGELES-Valerie Harper, who scored guffaws, stole hearts and busted TV taboos as the brash, self-deprecating Rhoda Morgenstern on back-to-back hit sitcoms in the 1970s, has died.

title: Trump Administration Aims to Reach 5G Agreement With Poland
summary: Effort comes as U.S. urges allies to cut ties with China's Huawei. The Trump administration is working with Polish officials to take steps toward protecting the security of that country's telecommunications systems.

title: Five Things About the Amazon Fires
summary: Resume Subscription. These aren't like the wildfires that have hit California and Siberia. In the Amazon, wildfires are fairly rare because it is a rainforest, which means it is damp most of the time and acts as a giant firebreak across much of South America. The Amazon fires are nearly all man-made.

title: Companies Say They Can Ignore Cost of U.S. Tax Rule
summary: Treasury regulations would retroactively unravel an international tax maneuver. Corporations say the rules aren't valid. Consumer-products conglomerate Newell Brands Inc., facing $180 million to $220 million in taxes because of Treasury Department antiabuse regulations, isn't recognizing those costs in its financial statement, contending the new rules aren't valid.

title: Ohio Attorney General Seeks Delay of Landmark Opioid Trial
summary: A.G. Dave Yost argues that only the state, not counties, can bring cases on behalf of the general public. Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost is asking an appellate court to halt a coming high-profile trial seeking to hold the pharmaceutical industry accountable for the opioid crisis, arguing the two Ohio counties pursuing the case don't have the legal authority to bring the claims.

title: Dead Angels Pitcher Had Opioids in His System
summary: Autopsy in Texas county after July 1 death also found high blood alcohol level.

title: Tehran Threatens a Think Tank
summary: The regime targets a U.S. group for opposing the 2015 nuclear deal.. As Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif negotiates with Europe to keep the 2015 nuclear deal alive, he sells the Islamic Republic as a normal government wronged by a rogue Trump Administration. This is a sham, and Tehran has proved it again by targeting an American think tank for retribution.

title: Beijing Moves on Hong Kong
summary: Police arrest democracy advocates and deny permits to march.. China appears to be making its long-expected move to crush dissent in Hong Kong, with arrests of pro-democracy lawmakers and activists and a ban on a march planned for this weekend. The crackdown is a gamble that the public will be cowed, but it could ignite even more resentment and protests.

title: U.S. Unveils Rules on Forgiving Student Loans After School Fraud
summary: Borrowers will have three years after they leave their schools to file a claim to have their debts canceled. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration will resume canceling the student-debt obligations of Americans who prove that their colleges defrauded them, under a long-awaited plan unveiled Friday.

title: Explaining the Methane Rule Panic
summary: When Big Oil agrees with the green lobby, inspect the details.. Environmentalists and Big Oil aren't as much at odds as they claim. Witness their joint opposition this week to the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal to ease methane regulation. The dirty secret is that the petrol giants don't mind rules that hurt small competitors.

title: Trump Says U.S. Not Involved in Failed Iranian Rocket Launch
summary: Officials believe the launch was an attempt by Tehran to advance its ballistic missile program. President Trump said Friday that the U.S. wasn't behind a failed Iranian rocket launch this week, and sent Iran "best wishes" in dealing with the aftermath of what U.S. officials suspect was an attempt to advance its ballistic missile program.

title: European Diplomats Swing Behind French Bid to Ease U.S.-Iran Tensions
summary: Initiative would provide relief from U.S. sanctions in return for Iran's full compliance with nuclear deal. HELSINKI, Finland-European diplomats are getting behind a French initiative to provide Iran economic relief from U.S. sanctions in return for its full compliance with a multinational nuclear accord, officials familiar with the matter say.

title: Japan to Beef Up Military With Money for Aircraft Carrier, U.S. Jet Fighters
summary: Defense Ministry is seeking $50.3 billion for the next fiscal year, up 1.2% from expected spending in the current year. TOKYO-Japan plans to start converting a destroyer next year into its first post-World War II aircraft carrier and make its first payment for Lockheed Martin Corp. F-35B jet fighters that can take off from the ship.

title: Trump Says Companies, Not Trade Policies, to Blame for Business Setbacks
summary: President defends trade policies ahead of new round of tariffs set for this weekend. WASHINGTON-President Trump rejected the notion that his trade policies were having a negative impact on the U.S. economy, instead blaming "badly run and weak companies" for any business setbacks and again urging the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.

title: Johnson & Johnson, J.M. Smucker, Best Buy: Stocks That Defined The Week
summary: U.S. stocks ended the week higher, with these companies among the most volatile. Sales are suddenly not so sweet for J.M. Smucker. The causes? Coffee, peanut butter and pet food. The company said falling prices for coffee and peanut butter, two of its key products, dragged sales down in its latest quarter. Smucker's pet-food business faced significant competition as other pet-food makers lowered prices for higher-end products to draw in consumers. Smucker bought the producer of the Rachael Ray Nutrish pet-food brand last year for $1.7 billion. Its rival General Mills Inc. has been expanding distribution of Blue Buffalo pet food products. Shares fell 8.2% Tuesday.

title: Stocks Break Losing Streak to End Volatile August
summary: Quiet session sends S&P slightly higher after month of sharp moves. Stocks snapped a four-week losing streak Friday to end a head-spinning August just a few percentage points below their all-time high.

title: Key Saudi Decision Maker Sees Role Diminished
summary: Blamed for the kingdom's lack of major foreign investment, Khalid al-Falih shifts to smaller energy focus. Khalid al-Falih, one of the architects of Saudi Arabia's plan to diversify its economy beyond oil, lost his role as the kingdom's chief industrial decision maker Friday, a move some Saudi officials said was due to his failure show progress on the kingdom's crucial reform plans.

title: Euro Tumbles to Two-Year Low After Weak Economic Data
summary: Many now believe ECB could unveil a big stimulus package at Sept. 12 meeting. The euro fell to a two-year low Friday as some investors bet that lackluster economic data would force the European Central Bank to further ease monetary policy next month.

title: Regulator Files Complaint Against Danske Bank, Saying Lender Misled Customers
summary: Danske said in June that it self-reported the case after conducting an internal investigation. Denmark's Financial Supervisory Authority said Friday it has reported Danske Bank A/S to the police for misleading its customers with one of its investment products.

title: A Feminist Capitalist Professor Under Fire
summary: The students who demand her firing, Camille Paglia argues, take prosperity for granted, are socially undeveloped, and know little about Western history. Who's Moses?. Philadelphia

title: John Locke Breaks His Silence
summary: A new manuscript is located in Maryland. But do Americans care what the philosopher has to say?. John Locke has a new article out, although he died in 1704. When England's King Charles II discovered a failed 1683 assassination plot against himself and his brother, he beheaded the plotters and started arresting opponents. Among the targets was Locke, who knew some of the conspirators but likely wasn't involved. Fearing for his life, Locke fled to the Netherlands. Before leaving, he deposited several manuscripts with Edward Clarke, a member of Parliament and trusted friend.

title: Hurricane Comey Was a National Disaster
summary: The bureaucratic rules he flouted are designed to protect the country from people like the FBI chief.. It is time to start reckoning with the consequences of James Comey.

title: The Free Spirits of Burning Man Meet the Man
summary: The heavy-handed federal government could regulate the eccentric annual gathering out of existence.. Pershing County, Nev.

title: A Famine of Fact at U.N. Climate Panel
summary: The IPCC sounds an alarm about food production, but another U.N. agency's data show it's a false one.. Global crop production sets new records virtually every year. That didn't stop the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change from publishing an alarmist report Aug. 8 that suggests global warming has devastated crop production and threatens food shortages.

title: Arrest of Hong Kong Activists, Rally Ban Set Stage for Clashes
summary: City enters 13th weekend of unrest with no end in sight for political deadlock. HONG KONG-The arrests of Hong Kong activists, including some of the most prominent figures of the pro-democracy movement, and the ban of a mass rally set the stage for a pivotal weekend showdown between protesters and the city's authorities, as the confrontation showed no signs of abating.

title: Military Judge Sets January 2021 Trial Date for Accused 9/11 Conspirators
summary: Government has sought to exclude evidence that defendants allegedly were tortured at CIA 'black sites'.

title: Google to Pay Millions in Fines Over Children's Privacy Issues at YouTube
summary: FTC settlement is expected to require significant changes at YouTube relating to its content directed at children. Google agreed to pay around $200 million to U.S. authorities investigating alleged abuses of children's privacy on the widely viewed YouTube video platform, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Hotter Soup and Snack Sales Lift Campbell's Results
summary: Food maker has cut costs, sheds some international businesses; shares jump. Campbell Soup Co. reported improved profitability in its latest quarter thanks to cost cuts and increased sales of soup and snacks in the U.S.

title: PC Makers Power Up After Dell Earnings
summary: Shares of personal-computer makers rally as Dell posts record revenue in PC division. A strong earnings report from Dell Technologies Inc. is giving shares of personal-computer makers a lift Friday, easing fears of a slowdown in the technology sector amid heightened trade tensions between the U.S. and China.

title: Campbell Turnaround Needs Time to Simmer
summary: Campbell shares rallied on early signs of a turnaround, but the stock is up sharply this year and investors should now await more evidence of improvement.. Investors are celebrating early signs of success at Campbell Soup , but the task of turning around its core soup business has only just begun.

title: CFOs Say They Underestimated Challenges of Lease-Accounting Standard
summary: Private companies preparing for the transition have been watching how public companies have implemented the new rule. Many U.S. public companies underestimated the difficulties of complying with a new lease-accounting standard, finance chiefs say. Their stumbles could inform private companies that are now preparing for the transition.

title: Jana Partners Takes 9% Stake in Bloomin' Brands
summary: Activist plans to discuss sale, board composition with the casual-dining chain. Activist hedge fund Jana Partners LLC has taken a 9% stake in Bloomin' Brands Inc. and plans to push for changes at the parent company of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant chain.

title: SEC Awards $1.8 Million to Whistleblower Reporting Alleged Overseas Misconduct
summary: The award is the latest given to a tipster who provided information on alleged misconduct committed abroad. The Securities and Exchange Commission awarded more than $1.8 million to a whistleblower whose information exposed alleged misconduct that occurred overseas, the agency said.

title: Lung Illnesses Linked to Vaping Rise, Says CDC
summary: Agency warns people not to buy e-cigarettes off the street or modify products they already own. Federal health officials warned the public on Friday not to buy e-cigarette products off the street or modify products that they already own, as the number of people who have developed severe lung illnesses after vaping significantly increased in the past week.

title: Triton, Goldman Sachs in Dispute with Creditor Group Over Galapagos Deal
summary: A judge will decide whether administration proceedings take place in Germany or the U.K.. European private-equity firm Triton Investment Advisers LLP and a group of lenders including Goldman Sachs International are in a legal dispute with junior creditors over struggling German industrial company Galapagos Holding SA.

title: Should Manners Still Matter in Our Time?
summary: The civil behavior in Mrs. Wharton's novels "The Age of Innocence" and "The House of Mirth" was reflective of an oppressive class of white elites living in extreme luxury while others were forced to play by their rules and live off their crumbs.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Mind Your Manners, Says Edith Wharton" (Declarations, Aug. 24): Progressives argue that civility (including its subset of manners and respect) is a construct to make people play by the rules of America's white patriarchy.

title: Los Angeles's Public-Transit System Declines
summary: For all the time wasted in traffic congestion, traveling by car still is far more efficient than public transportation, except in some high-density cities.. The congestion data cited in "Commuters Spend More Time in Traffic" (U.S. News, Aug. 23) is similar to that used by mass-transit supporters to promote spending on mass-transportation alternatives to personal auto transportation. What is usually missing is a time comparison of commuting in a car versus via public transportation.

title: The Nuclear Waste Is Safe. What About Other Waste?
summary: The casks used to store nuclear fuel are designed to withstand accidents worse than seismic events.. For the last 20 years, I have periodically evaluated the performance of used nuclear fuel in dry-cask storage-the same nuclear-waste form being considered for the Permian Basin sites in Texas and New Mexico ("Fight Brews over Nuclear Waste in Oil Patch," U.S. News, Aug. 15). I couldn't help see the irony in promoters of fracking, which according to the U.S. Geological Survey can increase seismic activity, worrying about the safety of dry-cask storage of nuclear waste. Nuclear waste always gets a bum rap, but it may be the only waste that is never purposely released into the environment. It is always managed, controlled and highly regulated.

title: Mayoral Election Raises Hopes for South Bend Revival
summary: Crime, corruption and weak job growth likely to dominate fall campaign.. Have South Bend, Indiana residents finally had enough of one-party rule? As Mayor Pete Buttigieg wraps up his second term, voters in this small and increasingly violent city will decide in November whether to elect their first Republican mayor in nearly half a century.

title: U.S.'s Move to Open Trails to E-Bikes Prompts Backlash
summary: Interior Department cites opportunities for disabled, while conservationists say order paves way for 'the complete motorization of America's remaining wild places'. A coalition of outdoors groups say they plan to try to block a new directive that allows electronic bicycles to use trails in national parks and other public lands long reserved for nonmotorized travel.

title: Labor Nominee Scalia Earned More Than $6 Million as Corporate Attorney
summary: Government disclosures show legal clients included Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, Facebook and Walmart. WASHINGTON-Eugene Scalia, President Trump's nominee to lead the Labor Department, earned more than $6 million since the beginning of last year as a corporate attorney, according to government disclosures.

title: Nickel Prices Soar to Near Five-Year High
summary: Futures prices on the metal jumped about 9% to their highest level in nearly five years. Nickel prices soared Friday after the Indonesian government said it would ban exports of nickel ore earlier than traders had expected, sparking concerns of shortages in the stainless-steel ingredient.

title: Orange Juice Slides as Hurricane Dorian Heads Toward Florida
summary: Futures turn lower after rallying all week; storm expected to land in south-central Florida on Labor Day. Orange-juice futures turned lower Friday after rallying all week as Hurricane Dorian heads toward Florida-a major provider of oranges for juice.

title: Iowa Democratic Party Scraps Plan to Allow Virtual Voting in Caucuses
summary: The Democratic National Committee raised questions about security issues and recommended dropping plan to allow some phone voting. The Iowa Democratic Party said Friday it would drop its plans to allow virtual voting in the state's presidential caucuses after the party's national committee raised security concerns.

title: General Electric Gets Most of Shareholder Lawsuit Dismissed
summary: Suit alleged yearslong fraud that inflated results in GE's insurance and power division; plaintiffs can amend claims. A federal judge dismissed much of a major shareholder lawsuit against General Electric Co. , knocking down several securities fraud allegations related to accounting at its insurance and power businesses.

title: Strength in U.S. Consumer Spending Drives Economy
summary: July spending data provides reassurance that economy's expansion continued to roll even as manufacturing cools. U.S. households ramped up their spending in July, providing reassurance that the economy's decadelong expansion continued to roll despite slowing factory activity and global growth.

title: Brother of Gymnast Biles Charged With Three Murders
summary: The siblings were raised by different family members after their mother lost custody. The brother of one of the most successful gymnasts in Olympic history has been charged in the killing of three people in a shooting late last year in Cleveland, according to local police.

title: Easy Fix to Cut Food Waste: Cleaning Up Date Labels
summary: Stamps like 'use by,' 'expires on,' 'best by' sow consumer confusion and waste; new labeling rules could help. The average American family spends $1,800 a year on food that is ultimately trashed, according to one estimate. But a simple fix could cut household food waste in half: better date labels.

title: Argentina's Presidential Front-Runner Says Country Is in a Virtual Default
summary: Alberto Fernández in interview partly blames IMF for country's financial crisis and pledges higher wages and pensions. BUENOS AIRES-Argentina's presidential front-runner said the government's new plan to restructure its short-term debt shows the country is virtually insolvent, as a crisis of confidence has wiped out private sector demand for government debt.

title: Energize Your Office With This Colorful, Shape-Shifting Cabinet
summary: Newly available in five rich, cheery hues, this container from Konstantin Grcic encourages you to swivel while you work. When not in use, Eileen Gray's 1920s cabinet appears to be a smooth, undisturbed unit, its straight lines finessed into a pleasing curve at one end. When opened, it performs an elegant choreography, each drawer swinging out elegantly from the frame. The wooden cabinet, designed for the pioneering Irish designer and architect's famed E-1027 villa in the south of France, epitomized her design ethos: modernist but not machine-like. Its four drawers, contained within a white-painted body, pivot outward to reveal their contents, creating a new dynamic between user and object: not the abrupt pull that traditional drawers require but a smooth, quiet, serpentine glide.

title: Fraudsters Used AI to Mimic CEO's Voice in Unusual Cybercrime Case
summary: Scams using artificial intelligence are a new challenge for companies. Criminals used artificial intelligence-based software to impersonate a chief executive's voice and demand a fraudulent transfer of €220,000 ($243,000) in March in what cybercrime experts described as an unusual case of artificial intelligence being used in hacking.

title: In a Dying Era, the Corrosion of an Everyman
summary: Alfred Döblin's epic novel 'Berlin Alexanderplatz' is An unsettling, penetrating portrait of a descent into fascism..

title: How Women Can Confidently Speak Up for What They Want
summary: The courage to advocate for yourself is a learned skill, according to a panel of experts on WSJ's Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast. Some women struggle with confidence, and this has real implications for their career advancement and pay.

title: Business Class on U.S. Airlines Is Finally Regaining Its Luster
summary: But only on some planes and some routes. Here's where to find the best premium-class cabins on coast-to-coast flights. FROM THE OUTSIDE, the Airbus A321 parked at LAX's Terminal 4 one day last spring looked no different from any of the thousands of narrow-body planes that trudge along on U.S. airlines' milk-runs around the country. But this was American Airlines Flight 2201, bound for New York's John F. Kennedy, and inside the plane's slender form, it had all the trappings of an international flight: enclosed suites in first class, a business class with sleeper seats, Champagne and fresh-brewed espresso on demand.

title: After Lengthy Delay, China's Communist Party to Meet in October
summary: Announcement follows an unusually lengthy delay that had set off speculation about the unity of the party leadership. BEIJING-China's Communist Party said it would convene a top policy-setting meeting in October, following an unusually lengthy delay that had set off speculation about the unity of the party leadership.

title: Illinois Debt Boosted After $14 Billion Bond Challenge Dismissed
summary: An Illinois judge rejected attempts to question the validity of bonds sold in 2003 and 2017. Illinois municipal bonds rallied Friday after a judge dismissed a petition that sought to restrain state borrowing and prohibit Illinois officials from making any more payments on $14 billion in debt.

title: If Everyone's Left San Francisco for Burning Man, Who Are All These People?
summary: Some residents swear the city is more livable when 'burners' leave for Nevada; we test the theory. SAN FRANCISCO-It's the most wonderful time of the year in the city, or so I'd been told.

title: Risky Seller Financing Flourishes Where Homes Are Cheapest
summary: 'Contracts for deed,' prone to abuse, are often only choice for buyers shut out of mortgage market. Poorer Americans buying inexpensive homes have few options in the conventional mortgage system. That has pushed them to a financing option full of pitfalls and prone to abuse.

title: India's Economic Growth Slows to Six-Year Low
summary: The country needs economic growth of about 8% to provide jobs for the millions of people who enter its workforce every year. NEW DELHI-India's economic growth slowed to a six-year low last quarter as debt problems at banks choked business and consumer spending in Asia's third largest economy.

title: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Declined at End of August
summary: Worries about a trade war chip away at consumer confidence. U.S. household sentiment fell in August from the earlier month amid concerns over a trade war.

title: Amid Italy's Beauty, a Vista of Decline
summary: The country's rich history contrasts with today's economic and political turmoil.. There was a joke that was popular when I was in college. "I had a great summer job this year," it went. "What was it?" went the reply. "I was prime minister of Italy."

title: A Tokyo Listing for Aramco Highlights Japan's Less-Stringent Disclosure Rules
summary: Saudi officials view Japan as a good option for an international offering, as Tokyo tries to regain status as an Asian financial hub. A Tokyo listing by Saudi Arabian Oil Co. would boost Japan's effort to re-establish itself as a global financial center, but it could also highlight areas in which the country has laxer disclosure standards.

title: Would Warren Buffett Buy Greenland?
summary: President Trump might consider writings of the Oracle of Omaha before making sovereign real-estate purchases. Warren Buffett's 89th birthday is a good occasion to revisit a question that has been weighing on financial minds lately-what price to put on Greenland.

title: U.S. Issues Sanctions Over Alleged Fuel Shipments to North Korea
summary: Fuel imports undermine bid to pressure Pyongyang into abandoning its nuclear weapons program, Treasury Department says. WASHINGTON-The U.S. on Friday placed sanctions on several Taiwanese- and Hong Kong-based firms and associated individuals for allegedly covertly shipping fuel to North Korea in violation of United Nations sanctions.

title: 'Guy': A Term Drawn From a Villain's Name Expands Its Reach
summary: As Billie Eilish's hit song shows, the word-derived from Guy Fawkes's failed 1605 plot to blow up the British Parliament-is no longer just for men. Last week, the inescapable "Old Town Road" by Lil Nas X finally ended its reign at the top of the pop charts. After the song spent a record-setting 19 weeks at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, the 17-year-old singer Billie Eilish toppled it with her mischievous "Bad Guy."

title: Fantasy Football Talk Is Here. Run For Your Lives.
summary: It's wildly popular and inspires fanatical devotion. But no one else really wants to hear about it.. Another football season is nearly upon us, which means another fantasy football season is upon us, and while I don't like to deliver bad news, it comes with the territory of writing this column, so here it is:

title: Mysteries: Chasing 'The Veiled Lady' Across the Globe
summary: An eclectic quartet of seasoned intelligence agents pursue the last uncaptured culprit in the Lincoln assassination.. 'The Sixth Conspirator' (Permuted Press, 359 pages, $26), Max Byrd's sophisticated historical novel of post-Civil War intrigue, takes place in 1867 and journeys from "Washington City" to London, Rome, Paris and back. Four people who collaborated with John Wilkes Booth in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln have already been hanged; a fifth plotter has at last been apprehended in Egypt. But government officials suspect that yet another conspirator is still at large. An eclectic quartet of seasoned intelligence agents is commissioned to go overseas and apprehend the elusive culprit.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: China's first Costco draws crowds, Mariachi dancers break world record, trampoline artists perform in Johannesburg and more.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Politics Books: The Agony of the Elites
summary: A pointed critique of egalitarianism on campus by former Yale Law School dean Anthony Kronman.. What is college for? The answers that colleges themselves give are almost exclusively utilitarian: A college education prepares you to succeed in the global marketplace, trains you to "think critically," and so on. Anthony Kronman proposes a very different answer. The true purpose of an undergraduate education, he argues in "The Assault on American Excellence" (Free Press, 272 pages, $27), is to induct students into an "aristocracy" of soul and mind.

title: 'Condé Nast' Review: The Showman Of Vanity Fair
summary: The modern magazine industry was practically invented by the man who first introduced regional ad offices, guaranteed circulation numbers and treated covers as flashy billboards for the publication.. People who aren't historians or followers of the magazine business can be forgiven for assuming that "Condé Nast" is a fictional brand figurehead, like Betty Crocker or Dinty Moore. That's how closely the name aligns in the popular imagination with the group of magazines published by Condé Nast Inc., currently including Vogue, Vanity Fair, Architectural Digest and the New Yorker. Indeed, a mental image of this Mr. Nast might be something along the lines of Eustace Tilley, the monocled, top-hatted dandy who used to be on the cover of the New Yorker's anniversary issue each February and now can be seen at the beginning of the Talk of the Town section.

title: 'Summertime' Review: 'A Genius, Without a Doubt'
summary: No one in the history of American music achieved so much, in so little time, as George Gershwin.. George Gershwin's reputation as a composer is still going strong 100 years after he emerged on the music scene, but probably not in the way he envisioned. Sheet-music sales don't generate much income nowadays, and Broadway has almost become a Disney theme park, but Gershwin calls the tune in other, unexpected places. You will hear his melodies everywhere from Starbucks playlists to United Airlines flight-safety videos. In fact, it's hard to think of another musician from the 1920s who looms so large over the broader culture. Consider the following news stories.

title: 'Prince Albert' Review: The Ultimate Victorian Gentleman
summary: Albert helped reinvent the British monarchy as a 'bourgeois' model for the rising middle class.. The British monarchy has twice been rescued by Germans. First, at the start of the 18th century, when the House of Hanover supplied the Protestant succession to the throne, ensuring the banishment of the Catholic Stuarts. Second, perhaps less obviously, in the mid-19th century, when Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha married Queen Victoria. So argues A.N. Wilson in "Prince Albert: The Man Who Saved the Monarchy," an engrossing biography that continues the author's long engagement with the Victorian age (most recently in "Victoria: A Life" and "Charles Darwin: Victorian Mythmaker"). Not only did Albert provide Victoria with a much needed emotional pillar and plenty of legitimate heirs, Mr. Wilson observes; he also modernized the monarchy to make it better serve the needs of the industrial age.

title: Fiction: The Unsparing Candor of an Italian Master
summary: The novels of Natalia Ginzburg ripple like razor wire with put-downs between loved ones.. Natalia Ginzburg's father, the eminent Italian scientist Giuseppe Levi, hated music, hated jokes, hated the government, hated smoking (even though he himself smoked incessantly), hated displays of sentimentality and emotion, and terminated most conversations with his wife and children by announcing, in a booming voice whose volume he had no ability to control, that they were "numskulls" and "nitwits." "He must have been a jackass!" he declared of Marcel Proust when his wife shared her love of his books. When that poor woman quietly asked the name of a university colleague standing nearby, Levi thundered, loudly enough for the room to hear, "Who's that? I'll tell you who he is. He's a perfect imbecile!"

title: Science Fiction & Fantasy: The Finest World-Builder Since Tolkien
summary: Michael Swanwick's twisty tale of a half-human changeling warrior is the third work to be set in his 'Industrialized Faërie' world, the most thoroughly imagined fictional realm since that of J.R.R. Tolkien.. Michael Swanwick's "The Iron Dragon's Mother" (Tor, 365 pages, $26.99) is the third set in his "Industrialized Faërie" world, first explored in "The Iron Dragon's Daughter" (1993). At the heart of the Faërie universe are the iron dragons, sentient war machines in the service of Her Absent Majesty, Queen of Babylonia. The dragons carry Sidewinder and Hellfire missiles, military lasers and Gatling guns, but they also have their own personalities, cold, coiled and malicious. They need pilots to control them, but since they are made of "cold iron," which is fatally carcinogenic to the aristocratic elves who rule Faërie, the pilots have to be half-human changelings snatched from our world. As with unicorns, the dragons will also tolerate only female-virgin pilots.

title: 'Doxology' Review: Love in the Age of Grunge
summary: Nell Zink's novels amusingly skewer the hubris of people who try to plan their lives. Her latest book follows Pam, who drops out of high school, joins New York's rock scene, then ends up married and raising Flora, another bold girl who wants to change the world.. With the precision of a sniper, Nell Zink nails the disorientation of coming of age in the 1980s. It was a time when all of the lush promises of "communal solidarity and LSD" gave way to a "haze of competition and AIDS." For Pamela Bailey, a central character in "Doxology," Ms. Zink's latest and most ambitious novel, being born in 1969 meant that "between her childhood and her adolescence lay a generation gap." Decades later, Pam's millennial daughter, Flora, is similarly dazed by a bait and switch, though in her case it's because she can't seem to put her fancy environmental-studies degree to good use. She assumed she would simply "find out who was saving the planet and offer to help," only to discover that no one, in fact, was saving the planet. The revelation leaves her reeling. "Was it all just a trick that had been played on her?"

title: 'Alive Still' Review: Taking Nothing for Granted
summary: Despite being stricken with polio, Nell Blaine developed a nimble style that owed as much to the Post-Impressionists of the 1890s as it did to the Abstract Expressionists of the 1950s.. If Nell Blaine had never been born, some screenwriter would have dreamed her up-and been accused of mawkishness. She was, in a sense, an archetypal figure of the midcentury Manhattan art scene: experimenting tirelessly with her paints, mingling with Frank O'Hara and Kenneth Koch, bedding everyone, male or female. Then, in 1959, she contracted polio. Waving aside her doctors' warnings that her hands were too frail to paint, she overcame her disability, relearned her trade and went on to produce a slew of brilliant oils and watercolors, cheered on by old friends and an adoring lover. (The biopic would have to be called "My Left Hand.")

title: Children's Books: From the Seuss Archives
summary: A goofy guide to horses in art, based on the beloved author's notes and sketches.. Theodor Geisel (aka Dr. Seuss) departed this world in 1991, leaving behind a box containing two unfinished midcentury manuscripts. One sheaf of rhymes and drawings eventually became the 2015 best seller "What Pet Should I Get?" Now the Australian illustrator Andrew Joyner has been tasked with spinning the second manuscript's sketches and ideas into "Dr. Seuss's Horse Museum" (Random House, 75 pages, $18.99), a picture book that shows children ages 6 to 9 the many ways that artists have represented horses.

title: 'March Sisters' Review: Meg, Jo, Beth & Amy
summary: Four 'Little Women' fans explore identity, mortality, feminism and gender roles.. Arecent, highly unscientific survey of female friends and family members revealed the following: They had all read "Little Women" (1868-69), Louisa May Alcott's chronicle of four sisters coming of age in cozy, genteel poverty under the watchful eye of their beloved, moralizing mother, Marmee, in mid-19th-century New England. They all adored the book and clung to their copies, often passing them on to their own daughters as though heirloom china.

title: Salman Rushdie Tilts at Our Strange Times
summary: In his 14th novel, 'Quichotte,' he uses his trademark magical realism to try to capture his sense of a surreal moment. At 72, Salman Rushdie has started thinking about the end of life and, incidentally, the end of the world. "I have the feeling that the world I've known is ending," he says over salad and scallops in Manhattan. "I have no idea what's coming next, but on the basis of what we see, it doesn't look great." He mentions, among other problems, the opioid crisis and racism.

title: Cheap Gas Revs Up Consumers, Boding Well for U.S. Economy

title: Exports Power Canada's Economic Growth to Two-Year High
summary: Energy and farm and fishing products propel recovery, but trade uncertainties and tepid consumer spending keep up rate-cut expectations. title: How to Achieve That Elusive Work/Life Balance? Take These Trips
summary: 'Holidays' in Havana, Marrakesh or Copenhagen designed to teach you to work smarter. THE DESTINATIONS ARE photogenic and the lodgings are indulgent, but don't call the "Bring it Back" experiences vacations. Designed by luxury travel outfitter Black Tomato with professional and personal growth in mind, the seven trips each come with a distinct purpose. In Copenhagen, you'll spend time with executives and journalists who advocate for the country's famously healthy work-life balance, sharing Danish strategies you can apply to your own too-work-y existence at home. "We have always encouraged our clients to travel with intention," said company co-founder Tom Marchant. "We wanted to take it a step farther and explore how it's possible to truly return transformed." Those who want to "shape and grow" their business can pursue insider tips in the Icelandic capital of Reykjavik. Creatively blocked? Head to Morocco where you'll meet the director of an innovative architecture firm and take guided trips to Marrakesh's souks and design district. Or book the trip to Cuba to visit with artists and art institutions, with the express purpose of igniting your own creative drive. blacktomato.com/us/bring-it-back

title: Christian Louboutin on the Shoes He Always Wears to the Airport
summary: The shoe designer talks to WSJ. about losing his passport, shopping in airports and the unusual souvenir he brings back from Cuba every year.. Christian Louboutin, the French footwear designer best known for the signature vibrant red soles on his company's shoes, has had a summer full of worldly travels. Ahead of visiting New York City next week to accept his 2019 Couture Council Award for Artistry of Fashion, Paris-based Louboutin has been spending time at his beach house on Portugal's Alentejo coast, traveling to Ireland for a wedding that turned out to be "too much fun" and making his annual pilgrimage to Cuba to see friends and purchase what he describes as the best avocados in the world. Here, he tells WSJ. about his packing philosophy, favorite carry-on bag and unfulfilled Dublin shopping list.

Yet he lost, and Federer knows one reason why: Top players win against servers more than ever before.

title: Japan's Sales-Tax Increase Threatens a Labor-Market Miracle
summary: Millions of jobs have been added to the Japanese economy in recent years, but progress seems to have stalled. That's not good news, since tumbling unemployment hasn't yet generated solid wage growth, and the sales tax is set to increase to 10% from 8% in just a month's time.

summary: China's plummeting hog population is a tailwind for U.S. meat producer Tyson Foods, despite the trade war. Ultimately, though, that might matter less than the carnage in China's own hog population following an outbreak of African swine fever. U.S. meat heavyweight Tyson Foods stands to benefit.

summary: Assembly Bill 5 would classify drivers for such companies as employees, a change pushed for by labor unions. title: New Mexico Attorney General Says State Should Reclaim Parts of Jeffrey Epstein Ranch
summary: Official says Epstein's leases on state lands never should have been granted, should be canceled. title: Proposed Opioid Deal With Purdue Draws Pushback
summary: States, including New York and Massachusetts, say potential $12 billion deal to settle more than 2,000 lawsuits falls short. A proposed deal for Purdue Pharma LP to resolve more than 2,000 lawsuits over its role in the opioid crisis is facing pushback from a vocal group of state attorneys general who say it doesn't bring in enough cash to satisfy their demands, according to people familiar with the matter.
